channel.title: Calling method with an array?
channel.description:
Ok this is basically what I want to do, I'm not sure if it's possible but either way I can't get it to work:
[code] String method = box.getText(); // possible input: close program."+method+"();// calls on static void close(); in program [/code]
That is the basic idea, although I've never seen anything like this but I'm sure there must be some way to do it?

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:18, topic:146634”]The thing is, he is talking about a method with the void return type.

Okay this is really confusing me. How do I add args to an already existing method?
Like, I understand what you guys are saying, I just don’t understand how to implement that into what I am doing

String input = voidmethodfield.getText(); //user input, name of existing method
Class c = Class.forName("client");//method's class, right?
java.lang.reflect.Method method = c.getMethod(""+input+"");//retrieves user input (name of method), if it exists in client?
method.invoke(null, "hai", "der");//invokes user input..but with what args??

Atm, it recognizes the void, but it gives me this…probably because of the arguments…

java.lang.NullPointerException

Look at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke().[/quote]
Hmm… Ty, this looks like something I was looking for

Read full topic

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @slay_blad3 slay blad3
item.description:
@slay_blad3 wrote:

Heh, thanks for pointing me to reflect, it turns out i was using the wrong class the whole time (l0l)

Its all good, it works without fail now

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

The thing is, he is talking about a method with the void return type.

[quote=“slay blad3, post:12, topic:146634”]Okay this is really confusing me. How do I add args to an already existing method?
Like, I understand what you guys are saying, I just don’t understand how to implement that into what I am doing

String input = voidmethodfield.getText(); //user input, name of existing method
Class c = Class.forName("client");//method's class, right?
java.lang.reflect.Method method = c.getMethod(""+input+"");//retrieves user input (name of method), if it exists in client?
method.invoke(null, "hai", "der");//invokes user input..but with what args??

Atm, it recognizes the void, but it gives me this…probably because of the arguments…

java.lang.NullPointerException[/quote]

Look at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke().

Read full topic

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“White Castle, post:15, topic:146634”]Actually, a void can’t be anything other than a method.

slay blad3, the first argument of java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke is the reference object. If the method is static, then you can leave it null. However, if isn’t, you must set it to the Object you’re calling the method from.[/quote]

sorry reverse that method != void

there fore dont use void for an over all name for methods ppl call Strings voids some times :0

Read full topic

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“White Castle, post:15, topic:146634”]Actually, a void can’t be anything other than a method.

slay blad3, the first argument of java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke is the reference object. If the method is static, then you can leave it null. However, if isn’t, you must set it to the Object you’re calling the method from.[/quote]

In Java void is also a data type, so if you wanted

Void v = cockSuck();

But it’s pointless

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

Actually, a void can’t be anything other than a method.

slay blad3, the first argument of java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke is the reference object. If the method is static, then you can leave it null. However, if isn’t, you must set it to the Object you’re calling the method from.

Read full topic

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Let’s say we have a class called ‘boobs.class’ and it has the following information:

public abstract class boobs {
public static void print(String str, String str2) {
System.out.println(str + str2);
}
}

Now, we want to call that non-instance method. We can do the following:

public class test {
public static void main(String[] s) throws Exception {
Class c = Class.forName("boobs");
java.lang.reflect.Method method = c.getMethod("print", new Class[] { String.class, String.class });
method.invoke(null, "hai", "der"); // can also be method.invoke(null, new Object[] { "hai", "der" });
}
}

Read full topic

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“slay blad3, post:8, topic:146634”]So I would need something like:

[code]
String input = box.getText();
try {
Class c = Class.forName(“program”);
Method meth = c.getMethod(“input”);
meth.invoke();
}
catch (Throwable e) {
System.err.println(e);
}

Like that?[/code][/quote]

no invoke has some arguments

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/reflect/Method.html

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @slay_blad3 slay blad3
item.description:
@slay_blad3 wrote:

So I would need something like:

String input = box.getText(); 
try {
            Class c = Class.forName("program");
            Method meth = c.getMethod(""+input+"");
            meth.invoke();
         }
         catch (Throwable e) {
            System.err.println(e);
         }

Like that?

Read full topic

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“Exception, post:4, topic:146634”][quote author=nueb35 link=topic=200687.msg1783135#msg1783135 date=1190870058]
would not work

Method.invoke();
[/quote]
When the method name is a string, how are you going to call invoke() on it?
Reflection is the way to go.[/quote]

what silver sayd Class.getMethod(args).invoke(); or Class.getMethods()[0].invoke(); // or method number xD

Read full topic

item.title: Calling method with an array?
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

Class.getMethod(String name,Class… params) is how you get the method from its name.
